    Update Your Piper via CLI

    Introduction

    The piper is a low cost, all in one, beautiful piece of equipment. It provides a cost effective solution for secure offline wallet generation. Comprised of a raspberry pi, thermal printer, and a single button for operation. It’s incredibly easy to operate, and functions entirely independently (just requires power). It also can even be plugged into a monitor, keyboard, & mouse to provide a graphical configuration interface / desktop environment. The other day I received an email stating that a new update was available. While I was excited for some of the changes (such as continuous printing), I was too lazy to plugin a monitor, keyboard, and mouse to initiate the upgrade. Instead I plugged it into my network, spent a minute looking at the upgrade script, and ran it from the command line.

    Download & Investigation

    I started out by downloading the update ( https://piperwallet.com/updates/update2.zip ) to my local machine and checked out the contents. Upon unzip’ing, I found it contains an Instructions.rtf & an update.tar file. The Instructions.rtf was filled with a detailed description on how to plug in the piper to a monitor, keyboard, and mouse; proceeding to untar the update.tar & run it by “double clicking.” Like I mentioned I’m way too lazy to do all of that :), so I plugged it into a free port on my router, plugged it in, and waited for it to showup on my dhcp table.

    While it was booting away I studied the contents of update2.zip a little more in depth. I began by untar’ing update.tar and was greeted with the following:

    ├── updater
│   ├── copyKeys.py
│   ├── data
│   ├── data1.sh
│   ├── data2.sh
│   ├── dist-packages
│   ├── updater
│   └── updater-src
│       └── updater.c

    I quickly checked out updater-src & was greeted with an incredibly simple C file that runs the following:

    #include <stdio.h>
int main(){
	system("/bin/bash /home/pi/Desktop/updater/data1.sh");
}

    Checked out data1.sh which simply calls data2.sh & sends a couple xmessage notifications to inform the user of the progress. I double checked data2.sh & found out it’s all simple command line arguments to backup the old & replace with the new.

    After examining the files at hand and becoming content with the expected results, I checked back on my router to see if anything had popped up.

    Bingo!

    I tried to ssh with a few default credentials, and failed. Went looking for the default raspberry login (it’s what piper is built on top of); and found out the default user:pass combo is pi:raspberry ; tried this & failed. Then tried pi:piper & was greeted with a console prompt.

    That was easy! I proceeded to transfer update.tar, run data1.sh, reboot, & enjoy my newly updated piper (ver1.05)

    #(on local machine) -- send update.tar to piper [user: pi ; password: piper] ; replace 10.1.1.115 with your ip
scp update.tar pi@10.1.1.115:
ssh pi@10.1.1.115
mv update.tar ~/Desktop
cd ~/Desktop
tar xf update.tar
cd updater
./data1.sh
#wait till complete :)
sudo reboot

    Conclusion

    After the reboot, you should be greeted with a happy stub of paper spit out the top of the piper. It’ll notify you of the successful update, and provide you a version number (like the first image in this post). Enjoy your newly updated piper & keep on printing on :)
